metadata.title: The determination of 2-phenylphenol in the presence of 4-chlorophenol using nano-Fe3O4/ionic liquid paste electrode as an electrochemical sensor

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate / jc is
Regular Article
The determination of 2-phenylphenol in the presence of 4-chlorophenol using nano-Fe3O4/ionic liquid paste electrode as an electrochemical sensor
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2019.07.047 0021-9797/ 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding authors at: Department of Chemical Engineering, Laboratory of Nanotechnology, Quchan University of Technology, Quchan, Iran and Univ Johannesburg, South Africa (H. Karimi-Maleh) and (O.A. Arotiba).
E-mail addresses: h.karimi.maleh@gmail.com (H. Karimi-Maleh), oarotiba@uj.ac.za (O.A. Arotiba).
Hassan Karimi-Maleh a,b,⇑, Colani T. Fakude b, Nonhlagabezo Mabuba b,c, Gbenga M. Peleyeju b, Omotayo A. Arotiba b,c,⇑ aDepartment of Chemical Engineering, Laboratory of Nanotechnology, Quchan University of Technology, Quchan, Iran bDepartment of Chemical Sciences, University of Johannesburg, South Africa cCentre for Nanomaterials Science Research, University of Johannesburg, South Africa
g r a p h i c a l a b s t r a c t
In this study, we suggested first analyt ical sensor and especially electrochemical sensor for simultaneous determination of 2-phenylphenol and 4- chlorophenol.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 9 June 2019 Revised 5 July 2019 Accepted 16 July 2019 Available online 17 July 2019
Keywords: 2-Phenylphenol 4-Chlorophenol Fe3O4 nanoparticle n-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluoro phosphate Water pollutants
a b s t r a c t
A voltammetric sensor was fabricated for the determination of 2-phenylphenol (2-PP) as a water pollutant. The sensor was prepared by modifying carbon paste electrode (CPE) with a composite of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (Fe3O4-NPs) and ionic liquid (n-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate; (HMPF6)). The Fe3O4-NPs was synthesized by co-precipitation and characterized by FESEM, MAP, AFM and XRD methods. The presence of Fe3O4-NPs and HMPF6 in CPE improved the catalytic activity of the electrode towards the oxidation of 2-PP. The Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE displayed two well separated oxidation signals in a solution containing 2-PP and 4-chlorophenol (4-CP). A peak separation of 380 mV was obtained, which implies that the sensor can be used for the simultaneous determination of the two water contaminants. The Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE displayed a linear dynamic range 0.01–520 lM for 2-PP. The sensor showed good recovery data for the analysis of 2-PP and 4-CL in orange rind, lemon rind and different water samples.
2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
ersity of

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Phenol-based organic compounds such as 2-phenylphenol and 4-chlorophenol have been reported to be toxic [1,2]. 2- Phenylphenol (2-PP) is one of the important agricultural fungicides that is usually applied post-harvest but its use as an additive is prohibited [3–5]. 2-PP has been used as a disinfectant in nursing homes, food processing plants, households, barbershops, hospitals, and laundries [6]. It is dangerous to the eye, the skin and it poses other health threats [6]. Owing to the toxicity of this compound, it is essential to control and determine its concentration in water and wastewater samples. On the other hand, 4-CL is another phenolic-based compound with wide application in industry [7]. It is often present in water samples as a result of the chlorination of phenols during disinfection [8]. This compound can cause many problems like cancer and liver problems for humans [9].
Electrochemical sensors with the excellent ability for determination of electro-active substances, especially water pollutants have been suggested as powerful analytical tool in recent years [10–20]. Electrochemical sensors are fast, portable and relatively cheap. There have been many reports on their use in monitoring environmental pollutants [21–30]. For example, the Tahernejad et al. reported an electrocatalytic analytical sensor for the determination of hydrazine in the presence of 4-CL using 2-chloro-N0-[1(2,5-dihydroxyphenyl) methylidene] aniline as a mediator. The coupling of mediator and NiO nanoparticles improved the ability of the sensor for trace level analysis of two pollutants in water samples [31]. Also, Bo et al. reported the only and first electrochemical sensor for determination of 2-PP using a graphite electrode modified with sodium dodecyl sulfate and investigated the electrochemical behavior of 2-PP in the concentration range of 1–4.0 lM [32].
Due to the need for rapid measurement of phenolic compounds, in this paper we report the first electrochemical sensor based on Fe3O4 nanoparticles and n-hexyl-3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate modified carbon paste electrode for the determination of 2-phenylphenol in the presence of 4-chlorophenol. The Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE displayed a high sensitivity 2-PP and 4-CL in the orange rind and different water samples and showed better dynamic range of limit of detection for the determination of these compounds compare to previous reported electrochemical sensors (Table 1).

sections.heading: 2.1. Instrument and chemicals
sections.text:
Iron trichloride, sodium hydroxide and iron (II) sulfate were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 2-phenylphenol and 4- chlorophenol were purchased from Acros Company. The n-hexyl3-methylimidazolium hexafluorophosphate was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used as a binder for fabrication of modified CPE. The graphite powder (<50 lm) and nujol oil were pur-
chased from Merck. A Potentiostats system (DropSens) with drop-view software was used for voltammetric investigation. The NAMA AFM Nano Technology system corporation (NATSYCO) and MIRA3TESCAN-XMU were used for morphological investigation.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of Fe3O4-NPs
sections.text: A 100 mL solution containing iron trichloride and iron (II) sulfate in a 2:1 M ratio was prepared and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Thereafter, sodium hydroxide (3.0 M) was added drop-wise to the solution under nitrogen gas. The obtained precipitate was filtered and then dried at 130 C for 16 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. Fabrication of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE
sections.text: Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE was fabricated by mixing 0.05 g Fe3O4NPs and 0.9 g of graphite powder in a mortar and pestle using ethanol as a solvent. The solvent was evaporated at a temperature of 60 C for 1 h and then the homogeneous powder was converted to paste using nujol and HMPF6 as binders. Copper wire was used to achieve electrical contact.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of Fe3O4-NPs
sections.text:
The structure and morphological properties of Fe3O4-NPs were investigated by XRD, AFM, FESEMD and MAP methods. The elemental analysis of Fe3O4-NPs (Fig. 1) display two elements, oxygen and iron, in the synthesized nano-powder. This confirms the purity of the synthesized Fe3O4-NPs.
The FESEM image of Fe3O4-NPs is presented in Fig. 2A. The spherical particles of Fe3O4-NPs (diameter 20.0 nm) can be seen in the image. The AFM image of Fe3O4-NPs is shown in Fig. 2B. This image also showed a spherical shape for synthesized of Fe3O4-NPs, this is consistent with the FESEM image. The XRD pattern of Fe3O4NPs is presented in Fig. 2C. There are six planes with miller indices [2 2 0], [3 1 1], [4 0 0], [4 2 2], [5 1 1] and [4 4 0]. These are matched with Fe3O4-NPs structure with the JCPDS card No. 74- 0748. The above characterization confirms the purity and crystalline structure of Fe3O4-NPs.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical behavior of 2-PP at Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE
sections.text:
The electrochemical redox process of 2-PP is often related to H3O+ concentration, therefore the redox behavior of 2-PP at pH range 6.0–8.5 was studied (Fig. 3A). The relationship between the Ipa and Epa of the oxidation signal of 2-PP vs. pH values was studied and the results are presented in Fig. 3B&C. The IPa of the oxidation signal of the 2-PP increased on increasing pH from 6.0 to 7.0. Further increase in pH led to a decrease in the signal, which indicate that the electro-oxidation of 2-PP was optimum at pH 7 (Fig. 3A).
the determination of 2-PP and 4-CL.
On the other hand, it was observed that Epa of the oxidation signal of 2-PP shifted negatively as pH increased with equation EPa(V) = 0.0675 pH + 0.8780, indicating that number of H3O+ and electrons were equal in the redox process (Scheme 1).
The electrochemical oxidation of 500.0 lM 2-PP was studied at CPE and different modified CPE (Fig. 4) and the obtained data relative to the values of oxidation potential and current of 2-PP at same solution condition are summarized in Table 2. The oxidation of 2-PP showed a low current response at unmodified electrode due to the effect of electrode surface fouling. Upon modification with Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6, however, a noticeable increase in the oxidation current of 2-PP was achieved and the anodic peak potential shifted to negative values. The improvement in the in the oxidation current and potential of 2-PP at the surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/ CPE is related to the rapid electron transfer rate of Fe3O4-NPs and HMPF6 at the surface of CPE.
The cyclic voltammograms of 2-PP were recorded at scan rate range 10–90 mV/s at surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE (Fig. 5 inset) with equation Ipa = 1.31115 m1/2 – 2.0939, suggesting that redox reaction of 2-PP was a diffusion-controlled process at the surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE (due to linear relation between current and m1/2) [33–38]. Using Tafel plot derivate from cyclic voltammo-
gram at scan rate 40 mV/s and in the presence of 400 lM 2-PP, the value of a can be calculated 0.64 (Fig. 6).
For a diffusion-controlled redox behavior process (2-PP in this case), the diffusion coefficient (D) could be determined by chronoamperometric investigation. The chronoamperograms of 100 lM, 200 lM and 300 lM 2-PP were recorded at applied potential 600 mV (Fig. 7A). Based on the slope of I t 1/2 curves (Fig. 7B), the D of 2-PP was estimated as 3.67 10 6 cm2/s.
3.3. Electrochemical determination of 2-PP in the presence of 4-CL at surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE
The oxidation redox response of 2-PP and 4-CL were measured by SWV at the surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE (not shown). The oxidation response of 2-PP and 4-CL increased linearly with their concentrations over the ranges 0.01 to 520.0 lM and 0.09 to 800.0 lM, respectively. The linear regression equations for 2-PP and 4-CL were IPa(lA) = 0.1776 + 0.0208C (lM) (r2 = 0.9971) and IPa(lA) = 0.1941 + 0.0099C (lM) (r2 = 0.9983), respectively. The detection limit of 2-PP and 4-CL were calculated to be 6.0 nM and 0.05 lM at the surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE.
The SW voltammograms of solution containing different concentration of 2-PP and 4-CL were recorded at Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/ CPE. The two separated oxidation signals at potentials 410 mV and 790 mV were recorded at Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE. t suggests that the sensor can be used for the determination of 2-PP in the presence of 4-CL. The calibration curves for 2-PP and 4-CL in the simultaneous investigation are presented in Fig. 8 B and C. For the simultaneous measurements of the concentrations of the pollutants at the surface of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE, we calculated sensitivities of 0.0201 lA/lM and 0.0093 lA/lM for 2-PP and 4-CL, respectively. These values of sensitivity are very similar to the sensitivity in calibration curve investigation. This confirms the ability of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE for determination of 2-PP in the presence of 4-CL without any interference.

sections.heading: 3.4. Stability and the reproducibility investigation
sections.text:
The stability and the reproducibility of the Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/ CPE as a sensor were investigated. The results of the electrooxidation of 500.0 lM 2-PP at the surfaces of five Fe3O4-NPs/ HMPF6/CPEs that were fabricated under the same condition are in Table 3. The results confirm good reproducibility of Fe3O4-NPs/ HMPF6/CPE as electrochemical sensor for determination of 2-PP. The oxidation current for 500.0 lM 2-PP was recorded in the period time 25 days and the result is given in Fig. 9. As can be seen, the
current signal still stands at 93.2% of the original signal after 25 days. This confirms that Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE as a sensor has a good stability.

sections.heading: 3.5. The ability of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE for real sample analysis
sections.text: The ability of Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE was checked for determination of 2-PP and 4-CL in orange rind and water samples. The results are displayed in Tables 4 and 5. The recovery data obtained are in the range 99.24–103.5% for 2-PP and 99.25–102.17% for 2-PP and 4-CL. These values are acceptable for new electrochemical sensor in real sample analysis.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The coupling of Fe3O4-NPs and HMPF6 as mediators for modification of CPE was investigated in this work. The Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/ CPE showed good sensitivity for the determination of 2-PP. The Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE was used as electrochemical sensor for determination of 2-PP in the presence of 4-CL with two separated oxidation signals (DEpa = 380 mV). The Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE showed detection limit of 6.0 nM and 0.05 lM for determination of 2-PP and 4-CL. Lastly, the ability of the Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE was checked for the determination of 2-PP and 4-CL in orange rind and water samples and good recovery data were obtained.
Scheme 1. Electro-oxidation mechanism of 2-phenylphenol.
Fig. 8. (A) Square wave voltammograms of 2-PP + 4-CL at concentrations of (a) 20.0 + 40; (b) 30.0 + 60; (c) 40 + 80; (d) 65 + 130; (e) 85 + 75 and (f) 110 + 200 lM. (B) Plots of the Ipa as a function of 2-PP concentrations. (C) Plots of the Ipa as a function of 2-CL concentrations.
Fig. 5. The relationship between the Ipa vs. m1/2 for electro-oxidation of 400 lM 2- PP. Inset) The cyclic voltammograms of 400 lM 2-PP at different scan rates; (a) 10, (b) 20, (c) 40, (d) 70 and (e) 90 mV/s.
Table 3 Summary of cyclic voltammograms results obtained for five Fe3O4-NPs/HMPF6/CPE towards 500 lM 2-PP, scan rate 100 mV s 1.
